title: “Sniffer” Rats are Trained To Sniff Out Tuberculosis and Land Mines!
text: “Sniffer” Rats are Trained To Sniff Out Tuberculosis and Land Mines! 12 Oct , 2015 Video Share Apopo, a nonprofit whose motto is: “We train rats to save lives.” So far, their rats have found nearly 60,000 landmines Africa and Asia, freeing up nearly 25 million square meters for safe habitation. Apopo prefers the African Giant Pouched Rat, who has a lifespan of about 8 years and is easier to train and be taught repetitive tasks due to its calm and trainable personality. How was this started? Back in 1995, Belgian student Bart Weetjens came across a study where gerbils had been used as scent finders, he came to the understanding that even rats could be trained to solve the global landmine problem, and would also be cheap, easy and smart to acquire. Two decades later, the super rats have helped seven nations get rid of buried threats, that otherwise unactivated, are deadly poisonous. Why rats? Well, in comparison to dogs, these rats only weigh two pounds, which isn’t enough to set off a landmine, so they can detect one easily without danger. These African Native varieties don’t bond with the trainers and are more sustained to survive in harsher climates.
